message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, amiodarone is known to prolong the QT interval but has a lower risk of torsades de pointes compared to other antiarrhythmic drugs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a ventricular tachyarrhythmia and is switched to another drug that prolongs the QT interval but is associated with a decreased risk of torsades de pointes. Amiodarone is commonly used for this purpose. Digoxin is not used for ventricular tachyarrhythmia, esmolol does not prolong QT interval, and quinidine is associated with an increased risk of torsades de pointes.

The drug that can replace ibutilide but has a lower risk of torsades de pointes is amiodarone. Digoxin, esmolol, and quinidine are not used to treat ventricular tachyarrhythmia.

Amiodarone is also used to treat tachycardia and fibrillation, but it has a lower risk of causing torsades de pointes compared to other drugs that prolong the QT interval. Therefore, Amiodarone was most likely administered to the patient.
